Beyond the Realm of Known Possibilities
MAN'S mastery of the earth was not a result
of physical prowess; strength alone would
have achieved but little in overcoming the prob-
lems confronting civilization. Put a jungle sav-
age, well versed in the ways of the jungle and
in primitive living, down in the midst of a jungle
minus weapons or companions and he is imme-
diately at the mercy of nearly any wild animal
that cares to attack. He cannot outrun nor best
In combat any animal of equal size nor many
much smaller. Even a few bees will put him to
flight, and an aggressive poisonous reptile will get
in a strike in spite of his best efforts.
But give him materials and he will fashion
for himself defensive weapons with which he need
not fear any animal, regardless of size. His
superiors in strength and speed are summarily
dispatched at a distance that precludes possi-
bility of injury to himself, and the lowly club,
man's first auxiliary weapon, is still suffcient
protection against the average reptile.
Why do not other animals do likewise? Why
is man the sole originator of auxiliary weapons
with which he may protect and preserve him-
self far better than with those supplied by na-
ture alone? Undoubtedly there was a large ele-
ment of luck attached--something in the unknown
past that deprived him of all defensive means ex-
cept those that he might conceive. Since lie was
forced to use his brain in his fight for life, it
was only natural that the brain would develop
out of all proportion to other parts of the body,
just as the breast muscles of birds, the leg
muscles of swift animals or the horn of the
rhinoceros have developed.
Brain, however, develops, not directly with
time or use, but, we might say, as a mathe-
matical power of time and use. This is perhaps
not technically correct but it expresses well the
idea. The more the brain developed, the faster
it developed; and, of course, the faster it de-
veloped, the more it developed. A sort of "nega-
tive resistance" effect, one might say; the best
and most advantageous feature of which is the
fact that there is no saturation point--no limit-
such as there is in physical development.
There has probably been more advance in the
last hundred years than in two thousand years
previous; and more in the past twenty years
than in the hundred previous to that, etc. Tho
advance in knowledge does not follow any law
with mathematical precision, but the "negative
resistance'' effect is plainly apparent.
It brings to mind the story of the blacksmith
who offered to shoe his customer's horse at the
rate of a quarter of a cent for the first nail, a
half a cent for the second, each nail costing
twice as much as the preceding nail. On first
consideration such an offer may sound ridiculous,
but the average worker would be financially wise,
if he were able to do it, to work under similar
terms for an employer, receiving one cent for
the first year, two cents for the next, and so on
for thirty years. The total amount received at
the end of the thirtieth year will be more than
many successful business men make in a simi-
lar period of time.
Who, then, dares limit the ability of man to
advance himself? Or who cares to risk future
ridicule by saying, "It will never be done," or,
"It may be done sometime, but not in our day?"
Impossible as some things seem to us now, they
become simplicity itself as soon as we learn how
to do them. Houdini nor Marconi nor the Wright
brothers were possessed of the devil, yet they
would have been burned at the stake a short
while ago if they had performed their respective
deeds then. Yet it was no more impossible then
than now; we simply considered such things
impossible (if thought of at all) because we did
not KNOW HOW.
With such brain power available to mankind
and with its use unlimited in the manner physi-
cal things arc limited, it is to be regretted that
only a small percentage of people use any ap-
preciable amount of it. One of our human frail-
ties is brain<lazincss. We would rather read in-
teresting fiction or go to a photoplay for mental
relaxation, than to read something which requires
real thinking ability to absorb. This is true re-
gardless of the recognized benefit that would be
returned in knowledge. We shy at reading a book
on medicine--even one on first aid--yet the value
of such knowledge cannot and is not disputed.
And the personal satisfaction of knowing what is
to be known today about the structure of the
atom or the universe, is ample compensation for
the time required to read it and to give some
thought to it.
Since this is realized only by those who like
to study such subjects, what is a better carrier
of scientific knowledge, or a better furtherance
of interest among the disinterested than a com-
bination of absorbing fiction with science? A
combination that will hold a reader's attention
by its interest; arouse his imagination by its
hint of prediction of the future or the hint of
uncovered insight into the past; and that will
bring into play a trend of thought that crcatc3
greater interest in and understanding of life.
A little love and sex is sometimes included, for
they will always stand out as a source of in-
terest in life, but they are not treated sordidly
in scientifiction; the nature of such writings is
such as to make these subjects of secondary im-
portance. Thrills and adventure are unlimited to
the writer of scientifiction because he is not held
down to human experiences and to the realm of
known possibilities. Instead, -his imagination may
wander into the unknown past, the unforeseen
future, the limitless space that surrounds us,
the infinitesimal volume of the atom, or the fu-
ture possibilities of electrical, chemical and me-
chanical research and invention.
Whoever can sit down and read such a tale
without thoroughly enjoying the play of imagi-
nation it creates and without learning something
deeper in life than he knew before, has no
place among those who may claim credit for
being an asset to mankind's progress through the
ages, for his brain-power, the power that placed
man on his present pinnacle, must not be of the
constructive type that is continually, by well
planned efforts, pushing on.
Viotor L. Osgood.
931 Cranford Ave.,
Bronx, New York.
Title Purposes of Scientifiction
ARE the two title purposes of scientifiction
equal? If not, there is danger of slighting
one of them, but if they are equal, we must
struggle hard lest wo slight both.
To the purpose of refreshing entertainment we
must give expert attention, as this is the aspect
we are most liable to slight. Each love-theme
should carry personality and be so woven into the
rost of the story that it takes mental effort to
isolate it. As an axiom we may say that real
science is not cold, and we may carry it out by
giving to the majority of our stories a pleasing
dominant tone. And we need not bo afraid of
fairy tales, as the average popular story is a fairy
tale, if you compare it with probability or wonder
why the two lovers are not followed through their
happiness ever after.
To the purpose of inspirational understanding
of science, we have already yielded attention.
Faithful psychology should be used throughout,
and a special study of the subject should be used
wherever convenient.
Now returning to the opening question, we note
that equality has not been quite fulfilled, the fic-
tion often getting the worst of it. Pure scientifio
speculation alone, if continued for years, is apt
to get monotonous. Likewise pure fiction is apt
to run dry. If then the two purposes are unequal,
they arc liable to approach cither of the two
extremes, as the case may be. and share the cor-
responding fate. But if the two objects are equal,
the possible combinations and results are probably
at a maximum, and that is why I believe that the
closer we come to attaining general equality, the
stronger will be our magazine.
Is scientifiction changing? So simple was the
original idea, better expressed probably by Jules
Verne than by Edgar Allan Poe, that one would
not expect change of an innocent thing like pre-
diction in pleasant narrative form. Yet we may
sec a faint outline of different stages of develop-
ment, rather more logical than chronological, for
some authors have almost jumpod to the higher
stages, and some authors may never reach them,
though they write forever.
The first stago, with its good taste and sim-
plicity, needs no commcnt. In the second stage
we have isolated specialization. Corresponding to
tragedy Jn ordinary fiction, wo have stories show-
ing a dark future for civilization; to comedy, a
dark present 3nd alluring future. More personal
subdivision has appeared in love stories, humorous
stories, dramatic tragedy, O'Henry endings, etc.;
but no deep-seated farce, in the same vein as on
the stage, has appeared. Tho possibilities of a
dramatic farce, in which the characters get all
mixed up, but do not know it until the reader
has nearly died of rapture, arc almost infinite.
The third stage was totally unexpected. Several
stories appeared lending a peculiar emphasis to
beauty. We thought when we started one of
those stories that it was a casual Arabian Nights
dream of riotous beauty. But we found the
author trying to express an elusive thought, an
uncrystallized goal; and trying, he gained artis-
tic taste, and succeeding he did not produce a
mere fairy talc, but thrilled us with a new phase
of art--shall we call it esthetic scientifiction f
W. Melvin Goodhue.

TRUE, we are prone to smile at times and ridi-
ctile the writer of scicntifiction. Yet I think the
more we read and listen to the urge to know, the
less wo will do this.
I have read stories that caused me to think a
great deal, especially as to the mechancial and
technical side. I wonder if certain mechanical
principles arc probable, from the writer's view-
point. I believe that therein lies the* secret of

A fellow reader once came to me with an object
that roughly resembled a telescope. He cxplaind that

of peering into the fourth dimension. Of course

I believe anything possible, yet I do want to

Following this, we arc confronted by the still

until I debated the question of the atom itself.
I ^a.vc a*ncc tried to picture a thousand suns in

Yet I like to think of the infinite, in small

History of Scientific Fiction
OF the origin of scientific fiction little need be
said. There arc traccs of the type in Greece,
where Aristophcnc's play, "The Clouds," took
place in an alchemist's laboratory; the Arabian
"Thousand Nights and a Night," offers various
examples of science in some of the stories.
Until the time of Poe, however, there was no
scientific literature of an influential character
written, with the exception of a few stories by
Bergerac (Voyages to the Sun and Moon), and
Swift (Gulliver's Travels). The evolution of
•the type really begins with stories such as
"Scheherazade's Thousand and Second Tale,"
"Mesmeric Revelation," and "The Balloon
Hoax."
For fifteen years after Poe there was a little fic-
tion of this kind written. In 1862, however, Jules
Verne turned his pen toward the scientific story
and published "Five Weeks in a Balloon." This
was followed by a "Trip to the Center of the
Earth" (1864), "From the Earth to the Moon"
(1865), "Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the
Sea" (1869), "The English at the North Pole"
(1870), and "Around the World in Eighty Days"
(1872). In these books, together with "Hector
Servadac" (1877), were begun the scientific typo
©f fiction and though their structure has been
modified, their subject-matter expanded, and their
craftsmanship developed, they remain almost per-
fect models of their kind, and they will always
<o remain, because their fundamental psychologi-
cal qualities--the very essence of their appeal--
embody the animating and motivating forces of
this branch of fiction. One can no more ignore
their basic form when writing a scientific novel
than one can ignore the experimental researches
of Marconi when building a radio.
After "Hector Servadac," probably his best
novel, Verne's work began to declinc and a new
author took his place. In 1895 appeared Wells'
'Time Machine" and "The Stolen Baccillus and
Others." In the same year he wrote "The Won-
derful Visit." These were followed by 'The
Island of Dr. Moreau" (1896), "The Plattner
Story and Others" (1897), "War of the Worlds"
(1898), "When the Sleeper Wakes" 1899, "The
First Men in the Moon" (1901), "Food of the
Gods" (1904), and ''The War in the Air"
It was Wells who carried on the tradition of
Verne in England and by giving impetus to the
scientific-fiction idea and purifying its technio
paved the way for the numerous writers of the
present day.
Until this time little had been done since Poe's
death in America. There had been one little-
known writer, Lu Scnarens, whose stories (writ-
ten about 1890) have proved marvelously pro-
phetic. With this exception, no books had been
written which added to the technic or subject-
matter of the scientific story.
After Wells, however, many American writers
entered the field. At the head of a long list
are such names as A. Merritt. Garrett P. Serviss
and A. Hyatt 4Vcrrill.
Of the foreign writers, Germany has Woll-
stonecraft, who wrote "Frankenstein," and many
others. In England there are many writers, in-
cluding Winsor (author of Station X). France
and Sweden also have many contributors.
In closing, a word should be said as to the
composition of the modern scientific story. This
should contain about twenty-five per cent pure
science, woven through almost any other type of
story. This may be a romance, as in Gerns--
back's "Ralph 124C 41-f," or a detective story, as
in Arthur B. Reeve's novels.
James T. Brady, Jr.,

Brooklyn, New York.
Words
TO most minds the word science conveys the
idea of verity, the writings or statements of
a "scientist" are accepted as authoritative and so-
called scientific conclusions are supposed to bo
absolute facts.
To the same minds the word fiction presents an
exactly opposite idea.
Whether the meanings commonly given to
words should be the accepted ones or not is de-
batable but there is no question that a new word
like Sciontifiction, designed to present a definite
idea to man's mind, should be exactly defined. Un-
less the definition is to be fabricated without re-
gard to the moanings of the sounds and forms
that have been used to convey certain ideas to
hearers and readers it should be constructed on
the basic meanings of those elements rather than
on the possibly erroneous one that usage has
given.

Science
FROM the beginning, when he first discovered
that he could reason, man has been search-
ing for the meaning of it all.
As he gazed into the infinite extent of the
heavens and beheld the twinkling of the evening
star, as he cowered in the entrance of some dark
cavern watching the fury of the elements de-
vastate his choice hunting grounds or as he gazed
in awe at the little green thing which had sprung
from the little seed which he had hidden in the
ground, he wondered. In his primitive mind was
bom that little spark which has meant more to
mankind than any other single emotion--The de-
sire to know, The desire to seek out and find
the meaning of all things.
Today that little spark has grown into a mighty
conflagration. We call it scientific investigation
or just science. So far-reaching is it in its effect
on mankind that the very basis of our modem
civilization is founded on it. No matter which
way we turn or what we do, in some manner wc
come in contact with the products of science.
Not only has it lightened the burdens of human-
ity. conquered most of its curscs, but it has
brought forth innumerable pleasures and con- s
vcniences and has brought forth the greatest
civilization the world has ever known.
More and more we are coming to recognize in
it tho greatest of all arts and to realize that the
greatest achievements of human endeavor are but
offspring of scientific investigation. Yet past
achievements in comparison to what is yet to be
discovered leads us to believe that wc are still in
the dark ages of scicntifio discoveries and that the
great truths yet loeked in the bosom of nature
are infinite in their possibilities. Thus the great
field of science is ever a great lure to the adven-
turous mind, taxing the keenest intellects by its
unfathomable mysteries.
Through the application of the laws of chem-
istry and physics, man and nature have changed
the first elementary forms of matter into an in-
finite number of different forms. These change#
are continually going on and each day brings
forth at least one new discovery in the scicntifio
world.
We have made wonderful strides in the last
few years and as we advance in wisdom and un-
derstanding, even greater discoveries will reward
our efforts. Yet regardless of our wisdom and
understanding, regardless of our wonderful
achievements now or henceforth man will have
created nothing. He will, even as nature has
for countless ages, merely have changed it in
form and substance. Man does not create tho
iron or steel which goes to make the great locomo-
tive or the steam that runs it. He merely changes
and adapts it to his own ideas. The power of
creation has. and always will belong to the Su-
preme Architect alone and man is merely fulfill-
ing his destiny in adopting it to his own needs
and uses.
In the advancement of scientific endeavor per-
haps no other single thing has played a greater
part than scicntifiction or scientific imagination as
we shall C3ll it. When we consider that prac-
tically all of the great inventions, reforms and
ideas have been foretold in fiction long before
they became a fact. When we consider that ali
of the great products and ideals of life must
first have been formed in the imagination of some
man's brain we can readily comprehend how
great an effect scicntifiction has had on tho
progress of science and invention. This scien-
tific imagination or scientifiction need not be the
product of some inventor's or scientist's mind
and in most cases is not. It merely starts a new
line of thought in their creative mind which
when worked out in its minutest details gives
to^ the world some new marvelous invention or
scientific discovery.
Each new scientific story, no matter how fan-
tastic it may sound, is a new step on the ladder
of scientific endeavor which some day will con-
tribute to the realization of some great scientific
discovery or invention.
Thus, as the rugged pioneer was the fore-
runner of civilization, so is scientifiction the fore-
runner of the marvelous inventions and scicntifio
achievements which arc to come.
H. A. Frazier,
240 Wabash Avenue,
Wichita, Kansas.

Is Progress Destructive?
[HOLD that Evolution, destroys nothing. That,
upon the contrary it ro-forms everything, ever
beJter ever greater on and on throughout eternity,
on beyond the scope of finite mind, and that
finito mind is itself a part of the process which
expands its scope in ceaseless endlessness.
The success of Scientifiction rests upon pre-
cisely the same factors as everything, as life
itself; those factors being the elements of which
it is composed, the same as those of any other
body, together with the elements influencing or
being influenced by it. It remains with the
directing power of the body to determine whether
it is to expand through the harmonious process
of evolution or be destroyed through the revo-
lutionary process of conflicting elements.
Science is one of the most absolute factors
known to man. Beyond its finality tho human
mind does not function though it blends with
and lends itself more readily to romance and
adventure than any subject yet discovered. Its
only parallel is perhaps the positivencss of the
sun in its relation to its own negative; light.

within the horizon of imagination, we erect struc-
tures of our desires toward which we struggle
and for which, we are paid in the coin of hopes

••pi rations.

tellectual development leads inevitably to self

versely, if it creates a mental atmosphere of

The Future of Scientifiction
SCIENTIFICTION romances quite commonly
deal with the likely social and scientific develop-
ments of days to come, but the future of tho
scientifiction story itself is not often considered.
We believe it merits as much attention as has
been given for example, the art of the short
story, for it is form peculiarly adapted to the
modem age and its astonishing growth in popu-
larity is rapidly lifting it from a dangerous prox-
imity to tho "nickle library."
This rise into good favor has been not a little
aided by the contributions of established authors.
Too, there have been writings on scientifiction
themes of such delicate beauty and astounding
imagery that they can hardly be denied a place in
the world's literature.
The novel as a literary form is not very old.
A hundred and fifty years or so has seen its rise
and development. It has been concerned with
the interrelations of mon and women, with em-
phasis upon character portrayal. As a form, it
will probably continue to lead all creative writing,
for we do not mean to suggest it is to be sup-
planted. But a now element has entered into our
life, touching every point and now entering our
literature. This is the machine.
Literature must welcome it. From all indica-
tions our living will be based upon machines for
some years, at least until the destructive folly of
man again halts progress. And, as some of the
tales have It, this may not be in any far dis-
tant day.
Until such a time, we look to scientifiction to
supply a considerable amount of imaginative im-
petus necessary to further inventive advance. In*
ventors and experimenters ace being presented
with a wealth of refreshing and stimulating ideas
which will multiply as time goes on.
This value is supplemented by another, the
really important educational work performed by
these stories in making their large group of read-
ers, well represented by the younger generation,
scientifically minded. We can picture almost any
cataclysmic crisis finding numerous folk quite fa-
miliar and able to cope with it.
These are the obvious benefits that the future
will bring. As our life grows more complex we
will demand more of fantasy in our reading as a
relief from the strain of existence. And since

mention is made in the editorial comment on
the story, of the likelihood of certain critics
picking out flaws in the hydraulics in tho
story. This set me thinking, and I have just
completed figuring various pressure values and
looking up the tensile strengths of glass and
•teel. Here are my conclusions:
Ordinary (fresh) water weighs approximate-
ly 62.4 pounds per cubic foot: but in the
case of Atlantis, we are dealing with sea
water which has a higher specific gravity
<103). Consequently sea water weighs 64.27
pounds per cubic foot, so that, at a depth of
exactly one mile (I am imagining that the
mean, or average depth of the Dome of At-
lantis is exactly 5,280 feet, the pressure would
be 339,356.16 pounds per square foot, or
169.678 tons per square foot. This is exactly
2356.64 pounds per square inch, which is a
small pressure when compared with those ob-
tained by investigators such as Basset, the
French experimenter. He obtained a pressure
of 25,000 kilograms per square centimeter
(page 214 of July, 1928, Science and In-
vention), which corresponds to 355,483.16
Pounds per square inch. This enormous pres-
sure (in liquid media, by-thc-way), was re-
tained by a steel cylinder two inches thick.
On making references, I found the ratio
in tensile strength of crown glass to United
States Tool Steel to be 1:76; therefore, a
similar ratio should exist with respect to abil-
ity to withstand pressure (if 1 am wrong
here, please inform me, Mr. Editor).
However, the fictitious Atlantcans were said
to have a super-glass, which would no doubt
be much stronger than ordinary glass--and
tho ratio given in the preceding paragraph
would be smaller.
If these figures are correct, I do not think
a single flaw can be found in the hydraulics of
"The Sunken World."

More Frequent Publication Asked for,
by a Reader. Professional Men
Read Amazing Stories
Editor, Amazing Stories Quarterly:
After having been "addicted" to your maga-
zine since its first appearance on the market,
1 thought perhaps, you would be interested in
an idea of mine which concerns the so-called
"wild stories" which you publish.
In the manuscript enclosed under separate
cover, I have tried to show that the afore-
mentioned "wild stories" have an important
place in literature, and are of inestimable
value to the average office man.
I have made inquiries concerning the types
of people who read your publication and have
formed, not to my surprise, ideas, which have
always seemed to be the concensus of opinion
in your discussion columns.
I have found that doctors, lawyers and busi-
ness men nuke up the most of your readers.
In not a few cases, I have also found that the
newsstand salesman himself, is an avid reader.
From one of the latter, I received a sugges-
tion which might be of interest to you. He
said that for the most part, people coming in
to his store were discouraged by the weird ap-
pearing covers, and the title. Amazing Stories.
It has always seemed to me a little child-
like, for a person of normal intelligence, to
wish to be amazed. It is a hard thing to ex-
plain, but I have had the feeling myself, when
picking up your publication, that I was afraid
someone was watching me--like a grown man
found playing with his small son's toy train.
It is probably a neuropathic viewpoint, but,
why would "Scientifiction" not serve equally
■well ?
There is another publication. "Weird Tales,"
by name, which is quite similar to your own.
The only difference seems to be, that they occa-
sionally print morbid articles and stories which
lack the sparkle and science of your contribu-
tions. I hope that your magazine never be-
comes "weird." The name, "Weird Tales,"
by the way, is another instance of the same
nature 3s that I have just observed upon. I
always hated to be seen buying it at a news-
stand. Much the same feeling exists when a
gray-haired old lawyer is asked to buy a "True
Confession" magazine for his young daughter I
The average man is looking for something
clean and different from the ordinary sex stor-
ies, sea stories, and so forth. I think that
your publication supplies this want, and, has
also promoted a greater elasticity of mind
among its readers. I know that it has been
the basis of several scientific arguments among
my friends--arguments which were only settled
by reference to books of physics and chem-
istry. In this way the public will force them-
selves to read books which they have heretofore
erroneously considered "dry." If there is any
way in which it would be possible to print
Amazing Stories oftener. I, for one, would
willingly go without dinner to make up the
extra expenditure!
Wishing you all the luck in the world, in
your forthcoming publications, I remain,
L. G. Townsend,
1040 Florida Street.
Los Angeles, Cal.
(The subject of frequency of publication of
Amazing Stories has been much discusscd and
carefully considered and we felt that the
Quarterly, with its increased size, solved the
problem of suiting everybody. Those who wish
a more frequent magazine can buy both, while
those who are content with a monthly publica-
tion can buy the monthly only. Wc are very
gratified if you have found that doctors, law-
yers and business men make up the most of
our readers. If anybody would take the
trouble to look at our covers, they will see
they are not weird in any sense, but arc care-
fully studied out by the artist who has proved
himself to have a special talent for scientific
subjects popularly treated. We certainly do
not propose to let our magazine become weird.
We can °n!y say regarding the more frequent
publication, that it is still in the future and
that the Quarterly indicates at least one step
in that direction.--EDITOR.)

(We do not publish the clipping you refer to, but
the subject of perpetual motion i9 very interesting.
At the present time, it is. in a sense, entering on its
third stage. A number of years ago, a doctrine
which was absolutely wrong was evolved and was
known as the Conservation of Force. This was
to the effect that the total amount of force in the
universe never changed. Tho truth is that it is per-
petually changed and this is the first stage of the
doctrine affecting perpetual motion. In the second
stage, tho doctrine was made intelligible and sen-
sible by stating that the sum of energy in the uni-
verse was fixed and unvaried. This was held as
an absolute matter of faith until recent times when
some doubt is beginning to be felt about it. If a
machine, in running or moving, would supply or
create the necessary energy to keep in motion for-
ever. that would be perpetual motion. From the
standpoint of ordinary physics and mechanics, no
such machine can be constructed and perpetual mo-
tion seems absolutely impossible in the mechanical
sense. It is hard to see how, any development of
molecular, atomic or electronic developments can
ever mako perpetual motion possible.--EDITOR)
